01747 
01748 /*  GHOST ENTITY SUPPORT */
01749 /*
01750 The triplet describing a ghosting "rule" (ghost dim, bridge dim, #
01751 layers) will be stored in the partition and re-established by the end
01752 of iMeshP_syncPartitionAll and iMeshP_syncMeshAll.  Implementations can
01753 choose to keep ghosting consistent throughout mesh modification, but ghosts
01754 are not required to be consistent until the end of these two functions.
01755 
01756 The number of layers specified is with respect to the global mesh;
01757 that is, ghosting may extend beyond a single neighboring processor if the
01758 number of layers is high.
01759 
01760 iMeshP_createGhostEntities is a preprocessing function.  It is
01761 cumulative; that is, multiple calls may add more ghosts, not eliminate
01762 previous ghosts.  
01763 */
01764 
01765 /* \brief Create ghost entities between parts/processors.
01766   * Ghost entities are specified similar to 2nd-order adjacencies, i.e.
01767   * through a "bridge" dimension.  Number of layers is measured from
01768   * the inter-processor interfaces.  For example, to get 2 layers of hex
01769   * entities in the ghost layer, measured from faces on the interface,
01770   * use ghost_dim=3, bridge_dim=2, and num_layers=2.
01771   *
01772   * Ghost information is cached on the partition.
01773   *
01774   * \param instance iMesh instance
01775   * \param partition_handle Partition on which to create ghosts
01776   * \param ghost_dim Dimension of entities ghosted
01777   * \param bridge_dim Dimension through which bridge adjacencies are found
01778   * \param num_layers Number of layers of ghost entities
01779   * \param err Error returned from function
01780   * \param include_copies  Create ghosts of non-owned part boundary entities?
01781   *         (1/0)
01782   * COMMUNICATION:  Collective.  Blocking.
01783   */
01784 void iMeshP_createGhostEnts(/*in*/ iMesh_Instance instance,
01785                        /*in*/ iMeshP_PartitionHandle partition_handle,
01786                        /*in*/ int ghost_dim,
01787                        /*in*/ int bridge_dim,
01788                        /*in*/ int num_layers,
01789                        /*in*/ int include_copies,
01790                        /*out*/ int *err);
01791 
01792 /* \brief Delete all ghost entities between parts/processors.
01793   * \param instance iMesh instance
01794   * \param partition_handle Partition on which ghost entities are deleted
01795   * \param err Error returned from function
01796   * COMMUNICATION:  None.
01797   */
01798 void iMeshP_deleteGhostEnts(/*in*/ iMesh_Instance instance,
01799                        /*in*/ iMeshP_PartitionHandle partition_handle,
01800                        /*out*/ int *err);
01801 
01802 
01803 /* \brief Return information about all ghosting on a partition.
01804   * \param instance iMesh instance
01805   * \param partition_handle Partition on which ghost entities are deleted
01806   * \param num_ghost_rules  Number of ghosting rules currently registered 
01807   * \param ghost_dim Dimension of ghost entities
01808   * \param bridge_dim Dimension of bridge entities
01809   * \param num_layers Number of layers of ghost entities
01810   * \param err Error returned from function
01811   * COMMUNICATION:  None.
01812   */
01813 void iMeshP_ghostEntInfo(/*in*/ iMesh_Instance instance,
01814                     /*in*/ iMeshP_PartitionHandle partition_handle,
01815                     /*out*/ int *num_ghost_rules,
01816                     /*inout*/ int *ghost_rules_allocated, 
01817                     /*inout*/ int *ghost_rules_size, 
01818                     /*out*/ int **ghost_dim,
01819                     /*out*/ int **bridge_dim,
01820                     /*out*/ int **num_layers,
01821                     /*out*/ int *err);
01822 
01823 /*--------------------------------------------------------------------------
01824             FILE I/O                                          
01825  --------------------------------------------------------------------------
01826 /* \brief iMeshP file I/O closely aligns with iMesh file I/O.  The major
01827  * change is the addition of a iMeshP_PartitionHandle argument to both
01828  * iMeshP_load and iMeshP_save, enabling I/O from parallel processes.
01829  * For now, individual implementations will support different sets of
01830  * options; Tim and Ken will work to unify the options by SC08.
01831  */
01832 
01833 /* \brief iMeshP_load: function to populate a mesh instance and 
01834  * a partition by reading data from files.
01835  * The application creates both the mesh instance and the partition
01836  * handle before calling iMeshP_load.  iMeshP_load then reads the
01837  * specified file, inserts entities into the mesh instance, constructs
01838  * parts within the partition, and inserts entities into the parts.
01839  * Optional capabilities of iMeshP_load include computing an initial
01840  * partition (e.g., if a serial mesh file without part assignments is read)
01841  * and creating ghost entities as requested by the application.
01842  * Options allow n>=1 files on p processes.
01843  */
01844 
01845 void iMeshP_load(iMesh_Instance instance,
01846                  const iMeshP_PartitionHandle partition,
01847                  const iBase_EntitySetHandle entity_set_handle,
01848                  const char *name, 
01849                  const char *options,
01850                  int *err, 
01851                  int name_len, 
01852                  int options_len);
01853 
01854 /* \brief iMeshP_save: function to write data from a mesh instance and 
01855  * a partition to files.
01856  * iMeshP_save writes mesh and partition data to the
01857  * specified file.
01858  * Options allow n>=1 files on p processes.
01859  */
01860 void iMeshP_save(iMesh_Instance instance,
01861                  const iMeshP_PartitionHandle partition,
01862                  const iBase_EntitySetHandle entity_set_handle,
01863                  const char *name, 
01864                  const char *options,
01865                  int *err, 
01866                  const int name_len, 
01867                  int options_len);
01868 
01869 
01870 /*
01871 ------------------------------------------------
01872 Major Items left to do:
01873 -  Support for multiple partitions.
01874    We discussed designating a given partition as 
01875    the "active" partition; i.e., the partition that is actually used in 
01876    the distribution of mesh data in distributed memory.  We were concerned 
01877    that when multiple partitions were used, multiple copies of mesh 
01878    entities would be needed to fully support multiple partitions at the 
01879    same time.  Designating one partition as "active" would store data 
01880    with respect to only one partition.
01881 -  File I/O support.
01882    Need common set of options to allow interoperability.
01883    Support single files, N << P files on P processes, and P files.
01884    Support reading and writing partition information.
01885    Support initial parallel partitioning of serial file data.
01886    Support storing mapping of parts to processes in files.
01887 
01888 ------------------------------------------------
01889 Minor Items left to do:
01890 -  Determine which capabilities need both "getNumX" and "getX" functions.
01891    That is, when would an application need "getNumX" to allocate memory
01892    for "getX" or separately from "getX".  When could we use only "getX"
01893    and return numX as a byproduct.
01894 
01895 -  Determine with functions need "Ent" and "EntArr" versions, or whether
01896    we should adopt only the more general "EntArr" version.
01897 
01898 -  Determine whether to revise iMeshP_createPartition to make it less MPI 
01899    specific.  We don't want to require applications to link with MPI if the 
01900    implementation doesn't require it.  We may define an ITAPS_Comm name 
01901    typedef'ed appropriately.
01902 
01903 -  iMeshP_getOwnerCopy could be achieved by calling iMeshP_getOwnerPart
01904    followed by iMeshP_getCopyOnPart.  Do we want to keep iMeshP_getOwnerCopy?
01905 
01906 -  Need function to receive tag data from part-boundary entities in owner.
01907    Possible options:  return the tag data values received directly, or 
01908    include a mathematical operation (similar to MPI_SUM). 9/15/08
01909 
01910 ------------------------------------------------
01911 Comments and resolved questions:  
01912 
01913 - Applications will build partitions by (1) creating a partition handle
01914   on each process to be included in the partition; (2) adding parts to 
01915   the partition handle within the process; (3) populating the parts with 
01916   entities, and (4) calling iMeshP_syncPartitionAll to allow the 
01917   implementation to compute global data for the partition.
01918 
01919 - For now, we will not include an iterator over local (to a
01920   process) parts within a partition.  If it is needed, it can be added
01921   later.
01922 
01923 - We will not provide capability to move entire parts to new
01924   processes;  instead, the new process must create the part in its
01925   partition handle and then receive (perhaps in bulk) the entities to 
01926   populate the part.  In other words, parts can be added to only a local 
01927   partition handle.
01928 
01929 - Currently, iMesh doesn't have the functionality to get entities or 
01930   entity sets by type and tag in serial.  Should it?  
01931   Many people said it would be useful; others said it could be costly
01932   (in parallel) or numerically difficult (for floating point values).
01933   This issue is an iMesh issue, not a parallel interface issue, so
01934   for this document, the issue is resolved.  The resolution:  If 
01935   iMesh adopts this capability, we will add it to the
01936   parallel interface.
01937 
01938 - We will not include functions that return all entities with 
01939   given characteristics within a partition; the memory use of these
01940   functions can be large.  Instead, we will return entity information
01941   with respect to parts and/or mesh instances.  If the user wants such
01942   info, he should go through the mechanics of gathering it himself so
01943   that he is painfully aware of how much memory he is allocating.
01944   Removed the following global queries:
01945   + All tag names over the partition;
01946   + All entities in this partition having a given type, tag and/or 
01947     tag name.
01948   + All entity sets in this partition having a given
01949     type, tag and/or tag name.
01950 
01951 - We will not include functions that return information about each
01952   part and/or process in a partition.  Such functions limit memory 
01953   scalability for large numbers of parts.  If the user wants such
01954   info, he should go through the mechanics of gathering it himself so
01955   that he is painfully aware of how much memory he is allocating.
01956   Removed the following global queries:
01957   + The number of entities in each part of the partition;
01958   + The number of entity sets in each part of the partition;
01959   + The number of entities with given type, tag, and/or
01960     tag name in each part of the partition;
01961   + The number of entity sets with given type, tag, 
01962     and/or tag name in each part of the partition;
01963   + All tag names in each part of the partition;
01964 
01965 - For functions that replace a set handle with a part handle, return
01966   all appropriate entities in a part, whether they are owned or are 
01967   copies.  The application can test for ownership if needed.
01968 
01969 - Part assignments computed with respect to a set of 
01970   entities induce part assignments to adjacent entities in an
01971   implementation-dependent fashion.  That is, if a partition is computed
01972   with respect to regions, queries about ownership of faces and vertices
01973   are valid.
01974 
01975 ------------------------------------------------
01976 Discussed but unresolved questions:
01977 
01978 - We discussed adding functions that give
01979   hints to an implementation about which data mappings the application 
01980   will use, allowing the implementation to pre-compute them if it chooses 
01981   to.  The example discussed was mapping between entities and parts, but 
01982   other examples in iMesh may also exist.
01983 
01984 - We discussed adding an iterator over entities 
01985   with given type/topology in a set or part.  We have non-iterator 
01986   functionality, but not an iterator.  
01987   KDD:  Is this true?  What is iMesh_initEntIter (and its analogous
01988   KDD:  iMeshP_initEntIter)?
01989 
01990 - We discussed storing in a partition 
01991   information about which "objects" were used in computing the partition.  
01992   These objects can be single entities or groups of entities.
01993   KDD:  Perhaps this capability should be part of the load-balancing service.
01994 
01995 - We discussed designating a given partition as 
01996   the "active" partition; i.e., the partition that is actually used in 
01997   the distribution of mesh data in distributed memory.  We were concerned 
01998   that when multiple partitions were used, multiple copies of mesh 
01999   entities would be needed to fully support multiple partitions at the 
02000   same time.  Designating one partition as "active" would store data 
02001   with respect to only one partition.
02002 
02003 ------------------------------------------------
02004 Not-yet-discussed, unresolved questions
02005 
02006 Entity questions:
02007 - From Carl:  "getTag*Operate: Again, we haven't got this in serial.  Does 
02008   the existence of such operations imply that we expect to implement 
02009   fields as tags? (Because that wasn't what I was assuming about field 
02010   implementations at all, personally...)  Note that I'm not opposed to 
02011   this sort of global reduction operation, I just wonder whether it'll see 
02012   use outside of field-like situations.  If not, then it should be in 
02013   parallel fields, not parallel mesh, and usage for 
02014   fields-implemented-as-tags should be handled there."
02015 */
02016 
02017 /*--------------------------------*/
02018 /* NOTES FROM BOOTCAMP MARCH 2008 */
02019 /*--------------------------------*/
02020 /*
02021 -  Changed getPartRank to getRankOfPart.  (Carl)
02022 -  Made sure iMeshP_getNumOfTypeAll and iMeshP_getNumOfTopoAll were
02023 documented as collective operations.  (Carl)
02024 -  Changed suffix "Par" to "All".  (Lori)
02025 -  Added iMeshP_testPart() to test status of part handle, returning
02026 LOCAL, REMOTE, or INVALID.  (Mark M, Lori).
02027 6/25/08:  Removed this function since part handles can no longer be remote.
02028 If an application wants to test the validity of a part handle, it can try
02029 to compute its Part ID.
02030 -  Changed iMeshP_addCopyOf and iMeshP_rmvCopyOf back to
02031 iMeshP_addGhostOf and iMeshP_rmvGhostOf.  If we wanted to use these
02032 functions for adding boundary copies, we'd have to include a list of
02033 already existing remote copies in the arguments, as well as
02034 communicate with parts already owning copies to let them know a ghost
02035 copy has been made.  Actually, this raises an interesting question:
02036 does a boundary copy need to know about all ghost copies of it?
02037 -  Change getEntParStatus to getEntStatus.  (Lori)
02038 -  Changed sendEntArrToPartsPar to exchEntArrToPartsAll.  (Lori,Tim)
02039 
02040 
02041 Parts and Processes:
02042 -  Martin argued for consecutive unique Part IDs in addition to or
02043 instead of Part handles.  He will send use cases.   If we decide to
02044 add them back to the interface, we could compute them in
02045 iMeshP_syncPartitionAll rather than in iMeshP_createPart.  That is, an
02046 application couldn't access them until after iMeshP_syncPartitionAll.
02047 6/25/08:  On follow-up, Martin couldn't recall why having consecutive
02048 PartIDs was necessary.  While we all agree they are conceptually nice,
02049 they are difficult to implement and not really necessary.  Part IDs will
02050 be globally unique but not necessarily consecutive.
02051 -  Are part handles globally unique?  They probably need to be
02052 globally unique in order for them to be useful as remote part
02053 handles.  Also, does the process rank need to be encoded in the part
02054 handle in order to map from parts to processes for communication?
02055 6/25/08:  DECIDED:  We will have globally unique part IDs.  Part handles
02056 will be valid for only local parts.  Accessing remote parts must be done
02057 via Part IDs.
02058 -  If in iMeshP_syncPartitionAll, we computed a mapping from part
02059 handles to integers 0,..., k-1, we could store only ranges of
02060 integers to achieve the part-to-process and process-to-parts mappings;
02061 this would require O(P) storage per process for P processes.
02062 6/5/08:  DECIDED:  Do not need getPartOnRank or getNumPartOnRank.  These
02063 functions were troublesome due to their storage or communication requirements.
02064 We decided to remove them.
02065 -  Alternatively, the mapping of all parts to processes can be stored
02066 in O(k) total memory, distributed across processors (e.g., a
02067 distributed data directory) but interrogating the directory requires
02068 communication.  
02069 6/5/08:  See note above.
02070 -  iMeshP_getPartsOnRank created discussion and needs to be resolved.
02071 IMeshP_getPartsOnRank would likely require either O(k) storage per
02072 process for k parts or communication.  For other points, please see
02073 Mark M's 3/12/08 email.  
02074 6/5/08:  See note above.
02075 
02076 CreateEnt:
02077 -  Carl asked if we should have a version of createEnt that accepts a
02078 part handle.  Should this function be used only for creating owned
02079 entities?   How do you envision creating part boundary entities when a
02080 parallel mesh is initially loaded?  
02081 
02082 Ghost entities:
02083 -  We currently have a mechanism only for pushing ghosts onto other
02084 parts.  Will we want a mechanism for pulling them, too?  (E.g., a
02085 part says, "I want ghosts for this entity.")
02086 
02087 PartNbor functions:
02088 -  Did we agree to remove the entity type from these functions?  That
02089 is, do we want to return the part IDs for all parts that have
02090 any copies?  The entity type was intended to allow us to get the part
02091 IDs for all parts that have copies of a given type (perhaps
02092 ALL_TYPES).  
02093 
02094 Functions handling both Parts and Entity Sets:
02095 -  Tim said these function names (e.g., iMeshP_getNumOfType,
02096 iMeshP_getAllVtxCoord) are too close to existing iMesh function
02097 names, even though the argument lists would be different.  He agreed
02098 to email suggestions for better names.
02099 
02100 Copies:
02101 -  Functions getNumCopies, getCopies, getCopyParts, and getCopyOnPart
02102 have different behavior for ghost and part-boundary copies.  Ghosts
02103 will return only itself and its owner in getCopies; part-boundary
02104 entities will return copies on other parts as well.
02105 -  Tim envisions applications (e.g., FETI methods) updating tag data
02106 in their copies that they would like to accumulate back to the
02107 owner.  Xiaolin said that he writes in his ghosts, but doesn't send
02108 those values back to the owner.  Currently, we have the ability 
02109 to send tag data only from owners to ghosts.  Tim will look at this issue
02110 and propose a solution.
02111 
02112 Communication:
02113 -  Although we should think in terms of parts, communication really
02114 occurs with respect to processes.  We need to make sure all our
02115 communication routines make sense with respect to both processes and
02116 parts, and perhaps, revise their descriptions.  Also, if we send to
02117 parts, the implementation really does need the mapping of parts to
02118 processes. 
02119 
02120 Entity Owner/Status Queries:
02121 -  Should we combine functions getEntOwnerPart and getEntStatus into
02122 one function?  Or should we combine functions getOwnerCopy and
02123 getEntOwner into one function?  Or should we remove getOwnerCopy and
02124 make applications call getOwnerPart followed by getCopyOnPart?
02125 
02126 Reducing storage:
02127 -  Mark Miller proposed allowing the user to specify the amount of 
02128 copying done by the implementation, depending on applications' needs.
02129 For example, for a static viz application, every boundary entity may not
02130 need to know where all its copies are, so the implementation would not
02131 have to store them.  Can the implementations accept a flag advising them how
02132 much copying is needed?  If so, the implementations could choose to 
02133 optimize storage or ignore the flag.
02134 */
02135
